39.1: Chapter 39 - How different the person who devotes himself to the study of the law of the Most High! He explores the wisdom of all the ancients and is occupied with the prophecies;
39.2: He preserves the discourses of the famous, and goes to the heart of involved sayings;
39.3: He seeks out the hidden meaning of proverbs, and is busied with the enigmas found in parables.
39.4: He is in attendance on the great, and appears before rulers. He travels among the peoples of foreign lands to test what is good and evil among people.
39.5: His care is to rise early to seek the Lord his Maker, to petition the Most High, To open his mouth in prayer, to ask pardon for his sins.
39.6: If it pleases the Lord Almighty, he will be filled with the spirit of understanding; He will pour forth his words of wisdom and in prayer give praise to the Lord.
39.7: He will direct his knowledge and his counsel, as he meditates upon God’s mysteries.
39.8: He will show the wisdom of what he has learned and glory in the Law of the Lord’s covenant.
39.9: Many will praise his understanding; his name can never be blotted out; Unfading will be his memory, through all generations his name will live;
39.10: Peoples will speak of his wisdom, and the assembly will declare his praise.
39.11: While he lives he is one out of a thousand, and when he dies he leaves a good name.
39.12: Praise of God the Creator - Once more I will set forth my theme to shine like the moon in its fullness!
39.13: Listen to me, my faithful children: open up your petals, like roses planted near running waters;
39.14: Send up the sweet odor of incense, break forth in blossoms like the lily. Raise your voices in a chorus of praise; bless the Lord for all his works!
39.15: Proclaim the greatness of his name, loudly sing his praises, With music on the harp and all stringed instruments; sing out with joy as you proclaim:
39.16: The works of God are all of them good; he supplies for every need in its own time.
39.17: At his word the waters become still as in a flask; he had but to speak and the reservoirs were made.
39.18: He has but to command and his will is done; nothing can limit his saving action.
39.19: The works of all humankind are present to him; nothing is hidden from his eyes.
39.20: His gaze spans all the ages: is there any limit to his saving action? To him, nothing is small or insignificant, and nothing too wonderful or hard for him.
39.21: No cause then to say: “What is the purpose of this?” Everything is chosen to satisfy a need.
39.22: His blessing overflows like the Nile; like the Euphrates it enriches the surface of the earth.
39.23: Even so, his wrath dispossesses the nations and turns fertile land into a salt marsh.
39.24: For the virtuous his paths are level, to the haughty they are clogged with stones.
39.25: Good things for the good he provided from the beginning, but for the wicked good things and bad.
39.26: Chief of all needs for human life are water and fire, iron and salt, The heart of the wheat, milk and honey, the blood of the grape, and oil, and clothing.
39.27: For the good all these are good, but for the wicked they turn out evil.
39.28: There are stormwinds created to punish; in their fury they can dislodge mountains. In a time of destruction they hurl their force and calm the anger of their Maker.
39.29: Fire and hail, famine and disease: these too were created for punishment.
39.30: Ravenous beasts, scorpions, vipers, and the avenging sword to exterminate the wicked: All these were created to meet a need, and are kept in his storehouse for the proper time.
39.31: When he commands them, they rejoice, in their assigned tasks they do not disobey his command.
39.32: That is why from the first I took my stand, and wrote down as my theme:
39.33: The works of God are all of them good; he supplies for every need in its own time.
39.34: There is no cause then to say: “This is not as good as that”; for each shows its worth at the proper time.
39.35: So now with full heart and voice proclaim and bless his name!

40.1: Chapter 40 Joys and Miseries of Life - A great anxiety has God allotted, and a heavy yoke, to the children of Adam, From the day they leave their mother’s womb until the day they return to the mother of all the living.
40.2: Troubled thoughts and fear of heart are theirs and anxious foreboding until death.
40.3: Whether one sits on a lofty throne or grovels in dust and ashes,
40.4: Whether one wears a splendid crown or is clothed in the coarsest of garments—
40.5: There is wrath and envy, trouble and dread, terror of death, fury and strife. Even when one lies on his bed to rest, his cares disturb his sleep at night.
40.6: So short is his rest it seems like none, till in his dreams he struggles as he did by day, Troubled by the visions of his mind, like a fugitive fleeing from the pursuer.
40.7: As he reaches safety, he wakes up, astonished that there was nothing to fear.
40.8: To all flesh, human being and beast, but for sinners seven times more,
40.9: Come plague and bloodshed, fiery heat and drought, plunder and ruin, famine and death.
40.10: For the wicked evil was created, and because of them destruction hastens.
40.11: All that is of earth returns to earth, and what is from above returns above.
40.12: All that comes from bribes or injustice will be wiped out, but loyalty remains forever.
40.13: Wealth from injustice is like a flooding wadi, like a mighty stream with lightning and thunder,
40.14: Which, in its rising, rolls along the stones, but suddenly, once and for all, comes to an end.
40.15: The offshoot of violence will not flourish, for the root of the godless is on sheer rock.
40.16: They are like reeds on riverbanks, withered before all other plants;
40.17: But goodness, like eternity, will never be cut off, and righteousness endures forever.
40.18: Wealth or wages can make life sweet, but better than either, finding a treasure.
40.19: A child or a city will preserve one’s name, but better than either, finding wisdom. Cattle and orchards make a person flourish; but better than either, a devoted wife.
40.20: Wine and strong drink delight the soul, but better than either, love of friends.
40.21: Flute and harp offer sweet melody, but better than either, a pure tongue.
40.22: Grace and beauty delight the eye, but better than either, the produce of the field.
40.23: A friend and a neighbor are timely guides, but better than either, a sensible wife.
40.24: Relatives and helpers for times of stress; but better than either, charity that rescues.
40.25: Gold and silver make one’s way secure, but better than either, sound judgment.
40.26: Wealth and vigor make the heart exult, but better than either, fear of God. In the fear of the Lord there is no want; whoever has it need seek no other support.
40.27: The fear of God is a paradise of blessings; its canopy is over all that is glorious.
40.28: My son, do not live the life of a beggar; better to die than to beg.
40.29: When one has to look to a stranger’s table, life is not worth living. The delicacies offered bring revulsion of spirit, and to the intelligent, inward torture.
40.30: In the mouth of the shameless begging is sweet, but within him it burns like fire.

41.1: Chapter 41 - O death! How bitter is the thought of you for the one at peace in his home, For the one who is serene and always successful, who can still enjoy life’s pleasures.
41.2: O death! How welcome is your sentence to the weak, failing in strength, Stumbling and tripping on everything, with sight gone and hope lost.
41.3: Do not fear death’s decree for you; remember, it embraces those before you and those to come.
41.4: This decree for all flesh is from God; why then should you reject a law of the Most High? Whether one has lived a thousand years, a hundred, or ten, in Sheol there are no arguments about life.
41.5: The children of sinners are a reprobate line, and witless offspring are in the homes of the wicked.
41.6: The inheritance of children of sinners will perish, and on their offspring will be perpetual disgrace.
41.7: Children curse their wicked father, for they suffer disgrace because of him.
41.8: Woe to you, O wicked people, who forsake the Law of the Most High.
41.9: If you have children, calamity will be theirs; and if you beget them, it will be only for groaning. When you stumble, there is lasting joy; and when you die, you become a curse.
41.10: All that is nought returns to nought, so too the godless—from void to void.
41.11: The human body is a fleeting thing, but a virtuous name will never be annihilated.
41.12: Have respect for your name, for it will stand by you more than thousands of precious treasures.
41.13: The good things of life last a number of days, but a good name, for days without number.
41.14: True and False Shame - Hidden wisdom and concealed treasure, of what value is either? Better is the person who hides his folly than the one who hides his wisdom. My children, listen to instruction about shame;
41.15: True and False Shame - Hidden wisdom and concealed treasure, of what value is either? Better is the person who hides his folly than the one who hides his wisdom. My children, listen to instruction about shame;
41.16: judge of disgrace according to my rules, Not every kind of shame is shameful, nor is every kind of disgrace to be recognized.
41.17: Before father and mother be ashamed of immorality, before prince and ruler, of falsehood;
41.18: Before master and mistress, of deceit; before the public assembly, of crime; Before associate and friend, of disloyalty,
41.19: and in the place where you settle, of theft. Be ashamed of breaking an oath or a covenant, and of stretching your elbow at dinner; Of refusing to give when asked,
41.20: of rebuffing your own relatives; Of defrauding another of his appointed share, of failing to return a greeting; Of gazing at a man’s wife, of entertaining thoughts about another woman;
41.21: of rebuffing your own relatives; Of defrauding another of his appointed share, of failing to return a greeting; Of gazing at a man’s wife, of entertaining thoughts about another woman;
41.22: Of trifling with a servant girl you have, of violating her bed; Of using harsh words with friends, of following up your gifts with insults;

42.1: Chapter 42 - Of repeating what you hear, of betraying any secret. Be ashamed of the right things, and you will find favor in the sight of all. But of these things do not be ashamed, lest you sin to save face:
42.2: Of the Law of the Most High and his precepts, or of justice that acquits the ungodly;
42.3: Of sharing the expenses of a business or a journey, of dividing an inheritance or property;
42.4: Of accuracy of scales and balances, of tested measures and weights; Of acquiring much or little,
42.5: of bargaining in dealing with a merchant; Of constant training of children, of beating the sides of a wicked servant;
42.6: Of a seal to keep a foolish wife at home, of a key where there are many hands;
42.7: Of numbering every deposit, of recording all that is taken in and given out;
42.8: Of chastisement for the silly and the foolish, for the aged and infirm answering for wanton conduct. Thus you will be truly refined and recognized by all as discreet.
42.9: A Father’s Care for His Daughter - A daughter is a treasure that keeps her father wakeful, and worry over her drives away sleep: Lest in her youth she remain unmarried, or when she is married, lest she be childless;
42.10: While unmarried, lest she be defiled, or in her husband’s house, lest she prove unfaithful; Lest she become pregnant in her father’s house, or be sterile in that of her husband.
42.11: My son, keep a close watch on your daughter, lest she make you a laughingstock for your enemies, A byword in the city and the assembly of the people, an object of derision in public gatherings. See that there is no lattice in her room, or spot that overlooks the approaches to the house.
42.12: Do not let her reveal her beauty to any male, or spend her time with married women;
42.13: For just as moths come from garments, so a woman’s wickedness comes from a woman.
42.14: Better a man’s harshness than a woman’s indulgence, a frightened daughter than any disgrace.
42.15: The Works of God in Nature - Now will I recall God’s works; what I have seen, I will describe. By the LORD’s word his works were brought into being; he accepts the one who does his will.
42.16: As the shining sun is clear to all, so the glory of the LORD fills all his works;
42.17: Yet even God’s holy ones must fail in recounting the wonders of the LORD, Though God has given his hosts the strength to stand firm before his glory.
42.18: He searches out the abyss and penetrates the heart; their secrets he understands. For the Most High possesses all knowledge, and sees from of old the things that are to come.
42.19: He makes known the past and the future, and reveals the deepest secrets.
42.20: He lacks no understanding; no single thing escapes him.
42.21: He regulates the mighty deeds of his wisdom; he is from all eternity one and the same, With nothing added, nothing taken away; no need of a counselor for him!
42.22: How beautiful are all his works, delightful to gaze upon and a joy to behold!
42.23: Everything lives and abides forever; and to meet each need all things are preserved.
42.24: All of them differ, one from another, yet none of them has he made in vain;
42.25: For each in turn, as it comes, is good; can one ever see enough of their splendor?

43.1: Chapter 43 - The beauty of the celestial height and the pure firmament, heaven itself manifests its glory.
43.2: The sun at its rising shines at its fullest, a wonderful instrument, the work of the Most High!
43.3: At noon it scorches the earth, and who can bear its fiery heat?
43.4: Like a blazing furnace of solid metal, the sun’s rays set the mountains aflame; Its fiery tongue consumes the world; the eyes are burned by its fire.
43.5: Great indeed is the LORD who made it, at whose orders it urges on its steeds.
43.6: It is the moon that marks the changing seasons, governing the times, their lasting sign.
43.7: By it we know the sacred seasons and pilgrimage feasts, a light which wanes in its course:
43.8: The new moon like its name renews itself; how wondrous it is when it changes: A military signal for the waterskins on high, it paves the firmament with its brilliance,
43.9: The beauty of the heavens and the glory of the stars, a shining ornament in the heights of God.
43.10: By the LORD’s command the moon keeps its appointed place, and does not fade as the stars keep watch.
43.11: Behold the rainbow! Then bless its Maker, for majestic indeed is its splendor;
43.12: It spans the heavens with its glory, the hand of God has stretched it out in power.
43.13: His rebuke marks out the path for the hail, and makes the flashes of his judgment shine forth.
43.14: For his own purposes he opens the storehouse and makes the rain clouds fly like vultures.
43.15: His might gives the clouds their strength, and breaks off the hailstones.
43.16: The thunder of his voice makes the earth writhe; by his power he shakes the mountains.
43.17: A word from him drives on the south wind, whirlwind, hurricane, and stormwind. He makes the snow fly like birds; it settles down like swarms of locusts.
43.18: Its shining whiteness blinds the eyes, the mind marvels at its steady fall.
43.19: He scatters frost like salt; it shines like blossoms on the thornbush.
43.20: He sends cold northern blasts that harden the ponds like solid ground, Spreads a crust over every body of water, and clothes each pool with a coat of armor.
43.21: When mountain growth is scorched by heat, and flowering plains as by fire,
43.22: The dripping clouds restore them all, and the scattered dew enriches the parched land.
43.23: His is the plan that calms the deep, and plants the islands in the sea.
43.24: Those who go down to the sea recount its extent, and when we hear them we are thunderstruck;
43.25: In it are his creatures, stupendous, amazing, all kinds of life, and the monsters of the deep.
43.26: For him each messenger succeeds, and at his bidding accomplishes his will.
43.27: More than this we need not add; let the last word be, he is the all!
43.28: Let us praise him the more, since we cannot fathom him, for greater is he than all his works;
43.29: Awesome indeed is the LORD, and wonderful his power.
43.30: Lift up your voices to glorify the LORD as much as you can, for there is still more. Extol him with renewed strength, do not grow weary, for you cannot fathom him.
43.31: For who has seen him and can describe him? Who can praise him as he is?
43.32: Beyond these, many things lie hidden; only a few of his works have I seen.
43.33: It is the LORD who has made all things; to those who fear him he gives wisdom.

44.1: Chapter 44 Praise of Israel’s Great Ancestors - I will now praise the godly, our ancestors, in their own time,
44.2: The abounding glory of the Most High’s portion, his own part, since the days of old.
44.3: Subduers of the land in kingly fashion, renowned for their might, Counselors in their prudence, seers of all things in prophecy,
44.4: Resolute princes of the flock, lawgivers and their rules, Sages skilled in composition, authors of sharp proverbs,
44.5: Composers of melodious psalms, writers of lyric poems;
44.6: Stalwart, solidly established, at peace in their own estates—
44.7: All these were glorious in their time, illustrious in their day.
44.8: Some of them left behind a name so that people recount their praises.
44.9: Of others no memory remains, for when they perished, they perished, As if they had never lived, they and their children after them.
44.10: Yet these also were godly; their virtues have not been forgotten.
44.11: Their wealth remains in their families, their heritage with their descendants.
44.12: Through God’s covenant their family endures, and their offspring for their sake.
44.13: And for all time their progeny will endure, their glory will never be blotted out;
44.14: Their bodies are buried in peace, but their name lives on and on.
44.15: At gatherings their wisdom is retold, and the assembly proclaims their praises.
44.16: The Early Ancestors - [ENOCH walked with the LORD and was taken, that succeeding generations might learn by his example.]
44.17: NOAH, found just and perfect, renewed the race in the time of devastation. Because of his worth there were survivors, and with a sign to him the deluge ended.
44.18: A lasting covenant was made with him, that never again would all flesh be destroyed.
44.19: ABRAHAM, father of many peoples, kept his glory without stain:
44.20: He observed the Most High’s command, and entered into a covenant with him; In his own flesh he incised the ordinance, and when tested was found loyal.
44.21: For this reason, God promised him with an oath to bless the nations through his descendants, To make him numerous as grains of dust, and to exalt his posterity like the stars, Giving them an inheritance from sea to sea, and from the River to the ends of the earth.
44.22: For ISAAC, too, he renewed the same promise because of Abraham, his father. The covenant with all his forebears was confirmed,
44.23: and the blessing rested upon the head of ISRAEL. God acknowledged him as the firstborn, and gave him his inheritance. He fixed the boundaries for his tribes and their division into twelve.

45.1: Chapter 45 Praise of Moses, Aaron, and Phinehas - From him came the man who would win the favor of all the living: Dear to God and human beings, MOSES, whose memory is a blessing.
45.2: God made him like the angels in honor, and strengthened him with fearful powers.
45.3: At his words God performed signs and sustained him in the king’s presence. He gave him the commandments for his people, and revealed to him his glory.
45.4: Because of his trustworthiness and meekness God selected him from all flesh;
45.5: He let him hear his voice, and led him into the cloud, Where he handed over the commandments, the law of life and understanding, That he might teach his precepts to Jacob, his judgments and decrees to Israel.
45.6: He also raised up, like Moses in holiness, his brother AARON, of the tribe of Levi.
45.7: He made his office perpetual and bestowed on him priesthood for his people; He established him in honor and crowned him with lofty majesty.
45.8: He clothed him in splendid garments, and adorned him with glorious vestments: Breeches, tunic, and robe
45.9: with pomegranates at the hem And a rustle of bells round about, whose pleasing sound at each step Would make him heard within the sanctuary, a reminder for the people;
45.10: The sacred vestments of gold, violet, and crimson, worked with embroidery; The breastpiece for decision, the ephod and cincture
45.11: with scarlet yarn, the work of the weaver; Precious stones with seal engravings in golden settings, the work of the jeweler, To commemorate in incised letters each of the tribes of Israel;
45.12: On his turban a diadem of gold, its plate engraved with the sacred inscription— Majestic, glorious, renowned for splendor, a delight to the eyes, supremely beautiful.
45.13: Before him, no one had been adorned with these, nor may they ever be worn by any other Except his sons and them alone, generation after generation, for all time.
45.14: His grain offering is wholly burnt as an established offering twice each day;
45.15: For Moses ordained him and anointed him with the holy oil, In a lasting covenant with him and his family, as permanent as the heavens, That he should serve God in the priesthood and bless the people in his name.
45.16: He chose him from all the living to sacrifice burnt offerings and choice portions, To burn incense, sweet odor as a memorial, and to atone for the people of Israel.
45.17: He gave to him the laws, and authority to prescribe and to judge: To teach precepts to the people, and judgments to the Israelites.
45.18: Strangers rose in anger against him, grew jealous of him in the desert— The followers of Dathan and Abiram, and the band of Korah in their defiance.
45.19: When the LORD saw this he became angry, and destroyed them in his burning wrath. He brought against them a marvel, and consumed them in flaming fire.
45.20: Then he increased the glory of Aaron and bestowed upon him his inheritance: The sacred offerings he allotted to him, with the showbread as his portion;
45.21: The oblations of the LORD are his food, a gift to him and his descendants.
45.22: But he holds no land among the people nor shares with them their heritage; For the LORD himself is his portion and inheritance among the Israelites.
45.23: PHINEHAS too, the son of Eleazar, was the courageous third of his line When, zealous for the God of all, he met the crisis of his people And, at the prompting of his noble heart, atoned for the children of Israel.
45.24: Therefore, on him also God conferred the right, in a covenant of friendship, to provide for the sanctuary, So that he and his descendants should possess the high priesthood forever.
45.25: For even his covenant with David, the son of Jesse of the tribe of Judah, Was an individual heritage through one son alone; but the heritage of Aaron is for all his descendants. So now bless the LORD who has crowned you with glory!
45.26: May he grant you wisdom of heart to govern his people in justice, Lest the benefits you confer should be forgotten, or your authority, throughout all time.

46.1: Chapter 46 Joshua, Caleb, the Judges, and Samuel - Valiant warrior was JOSHUA, son of Nun, aide to Moses in the prophetic office, Formed to be, as his name implies, the great savior of God’s chosen ones, To punish the enemy and to give to Israel their heritage.
46.2: What glory was his when he raised his hand, to brandish his sword against the city!
46.3: Who could withstand him when he fought the battles of the LORD?
46.4: Was it not by that same hand the sun stopped, so that one day became two?
46.5: He called upon the Most High God when his enemies beset him on all sides, And God Most High answered him with hailstones of tremendous power,
46.6: That rained down upon the hostile army till on the slope he destroyed the foe; That all the doomed nations might know the LORD was watching over his people’s battles. He was indeed a devoted follower of God
46.7: and showed himself loyal in Moses’ lifetime. He and CALEB, son of Jephunneh, when they opposed the rebel assembly, Averted God’s anger from the people and suppressed the wicked complaint.
46.8: Because of this, these two alone were spared from the six hundred thousand infantry, To lead the people into their heritage, the land flowing with milk and honey.
46.9: The strength God gave to Caleb remained with him even in old age Till he won his way onto the summits of the land; his family too received a heritage,
46.10: That all the offspring of Jacob might know how good it is to be a devoted follower of the LORD.
46.11: The JUDGES, each one of them, whose hearts were not deceived, Who did not abandon God— may their memory be ever blessed!
46.12: May their bones flourish with new life where they lie, and their names receive fresh luster in their children!
46.13: Beloved of his people, dear to his Maker, pledged in a vow from his mother’s womb, As one consecrated to the LORD in the prophetic office, was SAMUEL, the judge who offered sacrifice. At God’s word he established the kingdom and anointed princes to rule the people.
46.14: By the law of the LORD he judged the congregation, and visited the encampments of Jacob.
46.15: As a trustworthy prophet he was sought out and his words proved him to be a true seer.
46.16: He, too, called upon the mighty Lord when his enemies pressed him on every side, and offered up a suckling lamb.
46.17: Then the LORD thundered from heaven, and the tremendous roar of his voice was heard.
46.18: He brought low the rulers of the enemy and destroyed all the lords of the Philistines.
46.19: When Samuel neared the end of life, he testified before the LORD and his anointed prince, “No bribe or secret gift have I taken from anyone!” and no one could accuse him.
46.20: Even after death his guidance was sought; he made known to the king his fate. From the grave he spoke in prophecy to put an end to wickedness.

47.1: Chapter 47 Nathan, David, and Solomon - After him came NATHAN who served in David’s presence.
47.2: Like the choice fat of sacred offerings, so was DAVID in Israel.
47.3: He played with lions as though they were young goats, and with bears, like lambs of the flock.
47.4: As a youth he struck down the giant and wiped out the people’s disgrace; His hand let fly the slingstone that shattered the pride of Goliath.
47.5: For he had called upon the Most High God, who gave strength to his right arm To defeat the skilled warrior and establish the might of his people.
47.6: Therefore the women sang his praises and honored him for “the tens of thousands.” When he received the royal crown, he battled
47.7: and subdued the enemy on every side. He campaigned against the hostile Philistines and shattered their power till our own day.
47.8: With his every deed he offered thanks to God Most High, in words of praise. With his whole heart he loved his Maker
47.9: and daily had his praises sung; He added beauty to the feasts and solemnized the seasons of each year With string music before the altar, providing sweet melody for the psalms So that when the Holy Name was praised, before daybreak the sanctuary would resound.
47.10: and daily had his praises sung; He added beauty to the feasts and solemnized the seasons of each year With string music before the altar, providing sweet melody for the psalms So that when the Holy Name was praised, before daybreak the sanctuary would resound.
47.11: The LORD forgave him his sins and exalted his strength forever; He conferred on him the rights of royalty and established his throne in Israel.
47.12: Because of his merits he had as successor a wise son, who lived in security:
47.13: SOLOMON reigned during an era of peace, for God brought rest to all his borders. He built a house to the name of God, and established a lasting sanctuary.
47.14: How wise you were when you were young, overflowing with instruction, like the Nile in flood!
47.15: Your understanding covered the whole earth, and, like a sea, filled it with knowledge.
47.16: Your fame reached distant coasts, and you were beloved for your peaceful reign.
47.17: With song and proverb and riddle, and with your answers, you astounded the nations.
47.18: You were called by that glorious name which was conferred upon Israel. Gold you gathered like so much iron; you heaped up silver as though it were lead.
47.19: But you abandoned yourself to women and gave them dominion over your body.
47.20: You brought a stain upon your glory, shame upon your marriage bed, Wrath upon your descendants, and groaning upon your deathbed.
47.21: Thus two governments came into being, when in Ephraim kingship was usurped.
47.22: But God does not withdraw his mercy, nor permit even one of his promises to fail. He does not uproot the posterity of the chosen, nor destroy the offspring of his friends. So he gave to Jacob a remnant, to David a root from his own family.
47.23: Rehoboam and Jeroboam - Solomon finally slept with his ancestors, and left behind him one of his sons, Broad in folly, narrow in sense, whose policy made the people rebel. Then arose the one who should not be remembered, the sinner who led Israel into sin, Who brought ruin to Ephraim
47.24: and caused them to be exiled from their land.
47.25: Elijah and Elisha - Their sinfulness grew more and more, and they gave themselves to every evil

48.1: Chapter 48 - Until like fire a prophet appeared, his words a flaming furnace.
48.2: The staff of life, their bread, he shattered, and in his zeal he made them few in number.
48.3: By God’s word he shut up the heavens and three times brought down fire.
48.4: How awesome are you, ELIJAH! Whose glory is equal to yours?
48.5: You brought a dead body back to life from Sheol, by the will of the LORD.
48.6: You sent kings down to destruction, and nobles, from their beds of sickness.
48.7: You heard threats at Sinai, at Horeb avenging judgments.
48.8: You anointed the agent of these punishments, the prophet to succeed in your place.
48.9: You were taken aloft in a whirlwind, in a chariot with fiery horses.
48.10: You are destined, it is written, in time to come to put an end to wrath before the day of the LORD, To turn back the hearts of parents toward their children, and to re-establish the tribes of Israel.
48.11: Blessed is the one who shall have seen you before he dies!
48.12: When Elijah was enveloped in the whirlwind, ELISHA was filled with his spirit; He worked twice as many marvels, and every utterance of his mouth was wonderful. During his lifetime he feared no one, nor was anyone able to intimidate his will.
48.13: Nothing was beyond his power; and from where he lay buried, his body prophesied.
48.14: In life he performed wonders, and after death, marvelous deeds.
48.15: Despite all this the people did not repent, nor did they give up their sins, Until they were uprooted from their land and scattered all over the earth. Judah - But Judah remained, a tiny people, with its ruler from the house of David.
48.16: Some of them did what was right, but others were extremely sinful.
48.17: Hezekiah and Isaiah - HEZEKIAH fortified his city and had water brought into it; With bronze tools he cut through the rocks and dammed up a mountain site for water.
48.18: During his reign Sennacherib led an invasion and sent his adjutant; He shook his fist at Zion and blasphemed God in his pride.
48.19: The people’s hearts melted within them, and they were in anguish like that of childbirth.
48.20: But they called upon the Most High God and lifted up their hands to him; He heard the prayer they uttered, and saved them through ISAIAH.
48.21: God struck the camp of the Assyrians and routed them with a plague.
48.22: For Hezekiah did what was right and held fast to the paths of David, As ordered by the illustrious prophet Isaiah, who saw truth in visions.
48.23: In his lifetime he turned back the sun and prolonged the life of the king.
48.24: By his powerful spirit he looked into the future and consoled the mourners of Zion;
48.25: He foretold what would happen till the end of time, hidden things yet to be fulfilled.

49.1: Chapter 49 Josiah and the Prophets - The name JOSIAH is like blended incense, made lasting by a skilled perfumer. Precious is his memory, like honey to the taste, like music at a banquet.
49.2: For he grieved over our betrayals, and destroyed the abominable idols.
49.3: He kept his heart fixed on God, and in times of lawlessness practiced virtue.
49.4: Except for David, Hezekiah, and Josiah, they all were wicked; They abandoned the Law of the Most High, these kings of Judah, right to the very end.
49.5: So he gave over their power to others, their glory to a foreign nation
49.6: Who burned the holy city and left its streets desolate,
49.7: As foretold by JEREMIAH. They mistreated him who even in the womb had been made a prophet, To root out, pull down, and destroy, and then to build and to plant.
49.8: EZEKIEL beheld a vision and described the different creatures of the chariot;
49.9: He also referred to JOB, who always persevered in the right path.
49.10: Then, too, the TWELVE PROPHETS— may their bones flourish with new life where they lie!— They gave new strength to Jacob and saved him with steadfast hope.
49.11: The Heroes After the Exile - How to extol ZERUBBABEL? He was like a signet ring on the right hand,
49.12: And JESHUA, Jozadak’s son? In their time they rebuilt the altar And erected the holy temple, destined for everlasting glory.
49.13: Exalted be the memory of NEHEMIAH! He rebuilt our ruined walls, Restored our shattered defenses, and set up gates and bars.
49.14: The Earliest Patriarchs - Few on earth have been created like ENOCH; he also was taken up bodily.
49.15: Was ever a man born like JOSEPH? Even his dead body was provided for.
49.16: Glorious, too, were SHEM and SETH and ENOSH; but beyond that of any living being was the splendor of ADAM.

50.1: Chapter 50 Simeon, Son of Jochanan - Greatest of his family, the glory of his people, was SIMEON the priest, son of Jochanan, In whose time the house of God was renovated, in whose days the temple was reinforced.
50.2: In his time also the retaining wall was built with powerful turrets for the temple precincts.
50.3: In his time the reservoir was dug, a pool as vast as the sea.
50.4: He protected the people against brigands and strengthened the city against the enemy.
50.5: How splendid he was as he looked out from the tent, as he came from behind the veil!
50.6: Like a star shining among the clouds, like the full moon at the festal season;
50.7: Like sun shining upon the temple of the King, like a rainbow appearing in the cloudy sky;
50.8: Like blossoms on the branches in springtime, like a lily by running waters; Like a green shoot on Lebanon in summer,
50.9: like the fire of incense at sacrifice; Like a vessel of hammered gold, studded with all kinds of precious stones;
50.10: Like a luxuriant olive tree heavy with fruit, a plant with branches abounding in oil;
50.11: Wearing his glorious robes, and vested in sublime magnificence, As he ascended the glorious altar and lent majesty to the court of the sanctuary.
50.12: When he received the portions from the priests while he stood before the sacrificial wood, His sons stood round him like a garland, like young cedars on Lebanon; And like poplars by the brook they surrounded him,
50.13: all the sons of Aaron in their glory, With the offerings to the LORD in their hands, in the presence of the whole assembly of Israel.
50.14: Once he had completed the service at the altar and arranged the sacrificial hearth for the Most High,
50.15: And had stretched forth his hand for the cup, to offer blood of the grape, And poured it out at the foot of the altar, a sweet-smelling odor to God the Most High,
50.16: Then the sons of Aaron would sound a blast, the priests, on their trumpets of beaten metal; A blast to resound mightily as a reminder before the Most High.
50.17: All the people with one accord would fall with face to the ground In adoration before the Most High, before the Holy One of Israel.
50.18: Then hymns would re-echo, and over the throng sweet strains of praise resound.
50.19: All the people of the land would shout for joy, praying to the Merciful One, As the high priest completed the service at the altar by presenting to God the fitting sacrifice.
50.20: Then coming down he would raise his hands over all the congregation of Israel; The blessing of the LORD would be upon his lips, the name of the LORD would be his glory.
50.21: The people would again fall down to receive the blessing of the Most High.
50.22: And now, bless the God of all, who has done wonders on earth; Who fosters growth from the womb, fashioning it according to his will!
50.23: May he grant you a wise heart and abide with you in peace;
50.24: May his goodness toward Simeon last forever; may he fulfill for him the covenant with Phinehas So that it may not be abrogated for him or his descendants while the heavens last.
50.25: Epilogue - My whole being loathes two nations, the third is not even a people:
50.26: The inhabitants of Seir and Philistia, and the foolish people who dwell in Shechem.
50.27: Wise instruction, appropriate proverbs, I have written in this book— I, Yeshua Ben Eleazar Ben Sira— as they poured forth from my heart’s understanding.
50.28: Happy those who meditate upon these things; wise those who take them to heart!
50.29: If they put them into practice, they can cope with anything, for the fear of the LORD is their lamp.

51.1: Chapter 51 A Prayer of Thanksgiving - I give you thanks, LORD and King, I praise you, God my savior! I declare your name, refuge of my life,
51.2: because you have ransomed my life from death; You held back my body from the pit, and delivered my foot from the power of Sheol. You have preserved me from the scourge of the slanderous tongue, and from the lips of those who went over to falsehood. You were with me against those who rise up against me;
51.3: You have rescued me according to your abundant mercy From the snare of those who look for my downfall, and from the power of those who seek my life. From many dangers you have saved me,
51.4: from flames that beset me on every side, From the midst of fire till there was not a whiff of it,
51.5: from the deep belly of Sheol, From deceiving lips and painters of lies,
51.6: from the arrows of a treacherous tongue. I was at the point of death, my life was nearing the depths of Sheol;
51.7: I turned every way, but there was no one to help; I looked for support but there was none.
51.8: Then I remembered the mercies of the LORD, his acts of kindness through ages past; For he saves those who take refuge in him, and rescues them from every evil.
51.9: So I raised my voice from the grave; from the gates of Sheol I cried for help.
51.10: I called out: LORD, you are my Father, my champion, my savior! Do not abandon me in time of trouble, in the midst of storms and dangers.
51.11: I will always praise your name and remember you in prayer! Then the LORD heard my voice, and listened to my appeal.
51.12: He saved me from every evil and preserved me in time of trouble. For this reason I thank and praise him; I bless the name of the LORD.
51.13: Ben Sira’s Pursuit of Wisdom - When I was young and innocent, I sought wisdom.
51.14: She came to me in her beauty, and until the end I will cultivate her.
51.15: As the blossoms yielded to ripening grapes, the heart’s joy, My feet kept to the level path because from earliest youth I was familiar with her.
51.16: In the short time I paid heed, I met with great instruction.
51.17: Since in this way I have profited, I will give my Teacher grateful praise.
51.18: I resolved to tread her paths; I have been jealous for the good and will not turn back.
51.19: I burned with desire for her, never relenting. I became preoccupied with her, never weary of extolling her. I spread out my hands to the heavens and I came to know her secrets.
51.20: For her I purified my hands; in cleanness I attained to her. At first acquaintance with her, I gained understanding such that I will never forsake her.
51.21: My whole being was stirred to seek her; therefore I have made her my prize possession.
51.22: The LORD has rewarded me with lips, with a tongue for praising him.
51.23: Come aside to me, you untutored, and take up lodging in the house of instruction;
51.24: How long will you deprive yourself of wisdom’s food, how long endure such bitter thirst?
51.25: I open my mouth and speak of her: gain wisdom for yourselves at no cost.
51.26: Take her yoke upon your neck; that your mind may receive her teaching. For she is close to those who seek her, and the one who is in earnest finds her.
51.27: See for yourselves! I have labored only a little, but have found much.
51.28: Acquire but a little instruction, and you will win silver and gold through her.
51.29: May your soul rejoice in God’s mercy; do not be ashamed to give him praise.
51.30: Work at your tasks in due season, and in his own time God will give you your reward.
